message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms presented suggest glomerulonephritis, most likely caused by immune complex deposition. The presence of proteinuria and red cell casts supports this diagnosis. Diffuse mesangial IgA deposition is more commonly associated with IgA nephropathy. Complement-dependent and -independent reactions are less commonly associated with glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest nephritic syndrome, which is a glomerular disease. Among the options, only immune complex deposition is related to glomerular diseases. Diffuse mesangial IgA deposition is associated with IgA nephropathy, which presents differently. Complement-dependent and independent reactions are broad categories that do not specify a particular disease mechanism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The tea-colored urine, puffy face, hypertension, and abnormal urine analysis suggest glomerulonephritis. Among the options, immune complex deposition is the most common mechanism for glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest glomerulonephritis, a kidney condition characterized by proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension. Among the options, immune complex deposition is the most common mechanism of glomerulonephritis. IgA deposition is seen in IgA nephropathy, which is usually asymptomatic and not associated with hypertension. Complement-dependent and complement-independent reactions are not specific mechanisms of glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest that he has glomerulonephritis, which can be caused by immune complex deposition. This is supported by the abnormal urine analysis results, which includes proteinuria and dysmorphic red cells. The other options are not typically associated with glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including tea-colored urine, facial edema, proteinuria, and abnormal urinalysis, suggest glomerulonephritis. Among the options, only immune complex deposition is a common cause of glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension suggest immune complex deposition as the most likely mechanism. Diffuse mesangial IgA deposition may cause hematuria but not hypertension, and complement-dependent and complement-independent reactions are not typically associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation suggests glomerulonephritis, which can be caused by immune complex deposition. Other options are less likely to cause this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of proteinuria, dysmorphic red cells, and red cells in the urine indicates glomerular damage. The mechanism for this is immune complex deposition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of tea-colored urine, puffy face, proteinuria, and red cells in urine are suggestive of glomerulonephritis, and among the options, only immune complex deposition is associated with glomerulonephritis. Diffuse mesangial IgA deposition is associated with IgA nephropathy, which does not present with hypertension or facial edema. Complement-dependent and complement-independent reactions are not specific to any particular disease process.
